docs.lead_paragraph: After 15 years of fighting terrorists, American troops are training for hybrid wars: large conventional battles combined with insurgencies and cyberthreats.
docs.abstract: American military commanders are making sure that their troops know how to fight in conventional warfare, even after decade of counterinsurgency and counterterrorism campaigns; commanders envision future in which both types of warfare will have to be waged.

headline.print_headline: Behind Microsoft-Yahoo: The Online Economics of Scale

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR many online businesses, a Web site means never having to deal with a live person. The hope is that customers will find information about the business, order products and seek technical support online, 24 hours a day, at a fraction of traditional overhead costs. But that kind of customer service is only as good as the speed, accuracy and relevance of the information a site offers. How many people have abandoned a Web site in frustration, demanding to speak to a real customer-service person?
docs.abstract: NativeMinds chief executive Walter Tackett patents software technology called automated virtual representatives to conduct customer service, sales and marketing for online businesses; software uses computer-generated images to answer customer questions in real time using natural language; Tackett and co-inventor, Scott Benson, say technology can mimic human customer service operators at fraction of cost; Dan Erlin patents system for swiping credit card through TV remote control for use with television home shopping network, other applications (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent research has shown how some websites can produce results that perpetuate bias.
docs.abstract: The Upshot; studies find that software and algorithms can reinforce human prejudices, as they adjust what they perform based on people's behavior; companies can regularly run simulations to test results of their algorithms in effort to identify discriminatory output.

headline.main: How Exercise Can Help Us Learn

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. I want to install a program on my computer, but it requires a certain version and service pack of Windows XP to run. How can I find out if I have the version and service pack it needs? A. You can quickly find out what version of Windows your computer is running by going to the Start menu, clicking into the Run box and typing ''winver.exe'' (without the quotation marks). Click the OK button to call up the About Windows box, which should list the version of Windows XP and service pack installed on the machine.
